properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong easterly winds will whip up the snow and produce blizzard conditions today. Conditions will gradually improve overnight tonight. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T14:04:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T03:21:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1805577100.2020
Area: Kangiqsujuaq - Raglan Lake, Quaqtaq

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions forecast for Friday. Winds will strengthen Thursday night with gusts possibly reaching 100 km/h overnight. The winds combined with falling snow are forecast to produce blizzard conditions by Friday morning. The blizzard will end Friday night as winds start to diminish. Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to widespread poor visibilities. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T08:12:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-03T16:13:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1751040248.2020
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Very strong winds with gusts up to 100 km/h are forecast to develop starting overnight tonight. These strong winds combined with falling snow will produce blizzard conditions until Saturday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T12:31:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-03T20:32:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1410213105.2020
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong winds of 60 gusting to 90 km/h have developed in the Fort McPherson area. Winds are expected to diminish later tonight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T06:59:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-03T22:44:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4078629211.2020
Area: South Delta Region including Ft. McPherson - Tsiigehtchic
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong damaging winds and blizzard conditions have developed. Winds gusting as high as 90 km/h continue today. The combination of strong winds and 10 to 15 cm of fresh snow is producing blizzard conditions. The blizzard will continue tonight and end Friday morning as winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to widespread poor visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T14:48:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-03T22:49:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4058985357.2020
Area: Ulukhaktok

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds and blizzard conditions for Sachs Harbour today and Friday. Blowing snow with winds gusting up to 80 km/h overnight tonight, combined with 5 to 10 cm of fresh snow are producing blizzard conditions. The blizzard is forecast to continue through Friday afternoon, and end when winds diminish late in the day on Friday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T14:46:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-03T22:47:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1714287339.2020

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong easterly winds are forecast to develop in the Iqaluit area early this evening. Winds gusting to 90 km/h are expected giving reduced visibilities at times in blowing snow. Winds will gradually moderate overnight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T12:47:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-03T20:48:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3660814220.2020
Area: Iqaluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system will develop over the Eastern US Seaboard on Saturday and is expected to affect portions of Eastern and Central Quebec Saturday evening and on Sunday. This storm may bring significant snowfall amounts, strong winds, widespread blowing snow, as well as freezing rain. Although it is still early to forecast with certainty how much snow will fall and what areas will be hardest hit, the Lower St Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula could see up to 30 centimetres of snow. Freezing rain could also affect the Eastern Gaspé Peninsula. These poor weather conditions may have a significant impact on travel. Be prepared for changing and rapidly deteriorating driving conditions in heavy snow and blowing snow. Further details concerning this system will be provided as more information becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T12:41:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-03T20:42:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0295379930.2020
